awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Power Electronics-enabled Operation of Power  Systems, To Be In Chicago, IL, October 31 - November 1, 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
Power systems worldwide are going through a paradigm shift. Millions of distributed energy resources (DER) are being connected to power systems, which imposes unprecedented challenges to grid stability, reliability, security, and resiliency. Recent research has shown that it is promising to seamlessly integrate expertise in control systems, power electronics, and power systems to achieve power electronics-enabled operation of power systems to address these issues.  This workshop will invite 50 participants from funding agencies, regulatory commissions, utilities, think-tanks, vendors, and universities etc. to offer multidisciplinary perspectives on the paradigm shift of power systems and identify the associated challenges and needs, and potential tools and methodologies. Recommendations will be made after the workshop. This will help speed up the paradigm shift of power systems, improve the stability, reliability, security, resiliency of future power systems, promote sustainability, create jobs, and stimulate economic growth.

The fundamental challenge behind this paradigm shift is that future power systems will be power electronics-based, instead of electric machines-based, with a huge number of active, intermittent, non-synchronous, and heterogeneous players. The objective of this workshop is to bring experts from control systems,  power electronics, and  power systems together to identify fundamental challenges and needs in multidisciplinary research and education in control of power electronics-enabled power systems for enhanced grid stability, autonomy, scalability, operability, reliability, security, and resiliency;  strengthen collaborative efforts to tackle the challenges identified;  and raise the awareness of funding agencies and policy makers to support and nurture research and educational activities to advance fundamental knowledge, enabling technologies, and workforce in this area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Power systems worldwide are going through a paradigm shift as millions of distributed energy resources (DER) are being connected to power systems. This imposes unprecedented challenges to the operation of future power systems, which will be power electronics-based, instead of electric machines-based, with millions of active, intermittent, non-synchronous, and heterogeneous players. The aim of this workshop is to identify the fundamental challenges and needs in multidisciplinary research and education in control of power electronics-enabled power systems for enhanced grid stability, autonomy, scalability, operability, reliability, security, and resiliency, to strengthen collaborative efforts to tackle the challenges identified, and to raise the awareness of funding agencies and policy-makers to support and nurture research and educational activities in this area. The workshop was held at Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT), Chicago, on October 31 and November 1, 2019. The Organizing Committee of the workshop included Dr. Qing-Chang Zhong (Chair, IIT), Dr. Sairaj Dhople (University of Minnesota), Dr. Brian Johnson (University of Washington), Dr. Beibei Ren (Texas Tech University), Dr. Thanh Long Vu (Pacific Northwest National Laboratory), Dr. Ziang Zhang (Binghamton University), and Ms. Annette Lauderdale (IIT). Over 130 participants from funding agencies, regulatory commissions, utilities, national labs, universities, and vendors attended the workshop.

The Vice Provost for Research of IIT, Dr. Fred J. Hickernell, warmly welcomed all participants. Dr. Anil Pahwa from NSF opened the workshop with a talk entitled NSF Perspectives: Challenges and Opportunities, followed by 10 keynotes, 9 short talks, and 2 panel discussions. The participants also visited the IIT Microgrid and the SYNDEM Smart Grid Lab.

The keynotes delivered are

  • Enabling a Power Electronics Grid, by Deepak Divan (Georgia Institute of Technology)
  • Power Electronics-enabled Autonomous Power Systems: Synchronized and Democratized (SYNDEM) Smart Grids, by Qing-Chang Zhong (IIT)
  • Optimizing Ubiquitous Power Electronics for the Future Power Grid, by Zhenyu Henry Huang (Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)
  • Technical Challenges of High Level of Inverter-based Resources in Power Grids, by Robert Lasseter (University of Wisconsin -  Madison)
  • Research & Education in CURENT on Power Electronics for Power Systems, by Fred Wang (The University of Tennessee, Knoxville)
  • Growing Deployment of Power Electronics in Power Systems: Challenges, Opportunities, and Research Initiatives, by Abraham Ellis (Department of Energy)
  • Flexible Division and Unification Control Strategies for Resilience Enhancement in Networked Microgrids, by Mohammad Shahidehpour (IIT)
  • Medium Voltage Power Electronics Technology, by Alex Huang (University of Texas at Austin)
  • Power Engineering Education in the Age of Climate Crisis - A Holistic View, by Ned Mohan (University of Minnesota)
  • Power Electronics in Transportation Electrifications, by Ali Emadi (McMaster University)

The workshop was a great success and participants enjoyed it very much. Here are some sample feedbacks received. "I definitely got some ideas, established some networking links, and potential funding venues. In addition, based on the workshop presentations and discussions, I have already discussed some preliminary ideas with some of the attendees (that I met during the workshop) and plan to pursue collaborative research project(s)." "This was a great workshop bringing together the leading experts in the area for enlightening talks. We are looking forward to future collaboration particularly on integrating microgrid into undergraduate research and education. I am thinking to design a new course on microgrid modeling and control for undergraduates. This workshop definitely exposed me some new ideas on how to revamp the power systems and electronics curricula. Will ask you more on this in the future." "It will be wonderful if this workshop can be made into an annual event!" "The workshop was very well-organized and the talks covered different aspects of power electronics-enabled power systems. The demo/tour of the SYNDEM lab and the IIT microgrid were quite impressive! I enjoyed my visit at the workshop and interactions with many friends and colleagues."

The workshop was closed with some fun - a quiz. Participants were asked to use one single word to  summarize the workshop and the top words are "enlightening," "informative," "powerful," "forward-looking," "great," "excellent," "amazing," "futuristic," and "insightful."

The workshop was announced on LinkedIn and disseminated through IEEE Power Electronics Magazine, a leading magazine in the field, to reach a wider community.

As follow-on activities, the PI will be giving a keynote talk at the 46th Annual Conference of the IEEE Industrial Electronics Society (IES), Singapore, October, 2020, and the Organizing Committee members Ziang Zhang, Sairaj Dhople, and Brain Johnson organized a special session entitled Grid-forming Inverters in Future Power Systems at the same conference with six papers accepted.

For more details about the workshop including the slides, please visit http://peac.ece.iit.edu/events.
